reviewText: If you are a fan of Topcow Comics "Witchblade" then you know that the witchblade has had many wielders.  This is the story of the latest.  Set in Tokyo after a massive earthquake, our heroine is found alive holding her baby, our story starts 6 years later.  Our heroine is unaware that he possesses the witchblade and is on the move with her 6 year old daughter. Child welfare wants the girl as it is "best" for her, but little Rieko is just to smart for them.  Two mysterious organizations want the wichblade and there are mechanical people who want to eat her.  I will not destroy the volume by telling you to much, just know, there is depth to this story, there are several key players (good and bad) and lots of sub-players. And the ending leaves you wanting the next volume. Each episode is about a half our long so you are not being ripped off on content.

reviewText: Yikes, it is not Johnny Quest. At least not unless Johnny has changed a good deal. The Witchblade bearer, Masane, is more of an eyeful, even when not transformed by the Witchblade. Sorry, Johnny.The first four episodes of the Japanese TV series are included in this volume: The Beginning, Bewilderment, Defiance and Movement.I'd recommend watching the cast interview of the Japanese voice of Masane, Mamiko Noto, first, to get a feel for what this Japanese incarnation of the Witchblade series is about. I must have lived in a cave in recent years as I was not aware of the U.S. comic or the U.S. television show. The interview with Marc Silvestri, of Top Gun and Witchblade, could also be useful to watch before viewing the episodes.I've only seen one other anime, "Spirted Away" and it would be unfair to use that as a standard. The drawing here is, appropriately, quite comic-book-ish. The pace is a bit slow. As Mamiko Noto explains and as will become apparent as you watch the episodes, the emphasis isn't on the action as on the relationship of the characters, especially the relationship of the Witchblade bearer, Masane, and her daugher Rihokoo ("Riko").The plot isn't hard to follow but is entertaining.Perhaps some gaps will be filled in in subsequent episodes but I could follow along well enough. You may, however, find yourself saying, as did the police in the first episode, "What the hell is that thing?"The transformations of Masane under the Witchblade's power into a savage fighter are impressive. Not the kind of women you'd want to tangle with  as she is challenged the various fighting machines she will encounter in Tokyo. The ex-con products, designed to be "human-like" (with a sinister "I have to make her warm") have been killing women and the corporation that produced them wants Masane's help (transformed into the Witchblade as she encounters each one) to eliminate them.I especially enjoyed the music and in particular the opening theme's song "XTC" by Psychic Lover:"Give me your XTC,I don't need your false love,I will accept it, sin and punishment."Has a nice ring, don't you think? Maybe you have to hear it song with the accompanying graphics to really appreciate it. Perhaps it refers to the demands the Witchblade is making upon Masane.It seems at least as much effort went into the opening and closing themes as into the four episodes collected so far on this DVD. One downside is each episode contains the opening and closing theme (which are also included among the Extras). After watching them once, I fast-forwarded over them and later enjoyed them when I found them among the Extras. The song in the closing theme was song by the Japanese voice of Masane, Mamiko Noto, as she reveals in her interview.Subtitles are used sparingly. The voices on this DVD (except for the songs) are English; many of the signs are in Japanese but salient ones are subtitled.Since I didn't know the comic book or TV show, I wasn't bothered by comparisons to these. Masane is a new bearer of the Witchblade, which chose her when it found her with her newborn 6 years before the episodes begin, at the null point of a strong quake. Amnesiac, she nevertheless had a maternity diary with her, so that the newly formed Child Welfare permitted to keep her daughter but episode 1 begins with that being called into question.I had to appreciate, given how often U.S. TV shows and movies show people in cars without seatbeats, that Masane would buckle up.As promised on the product page, I found the Easter Egg without much trouble. If you find it and watch, you'll know, among other things, what kind of present Marc Silvestri may not want more of.At the end of Mamiko Noto's interview, she promises that, with future episodes, the story will become more interesting as the human drama unfolds. Episode 4 and so Volume 1 end with a real cliffhanger, as the transformed Masane faces a new challenge.What a plight for Masane and Riko, caught up by the Witchblade as well as powerful institutions with their harmful products. Not a fate I'd wish on anyone, let alone these two gentle albeit gutsy gals.It's all catchy and cool. While I would have preferred more action and less attention to the mother-daughter relationship, their bond may become more relevant to the plot in future episodes. A good start.N.B. Please see comments, I added some information and concern about the rating, if "unrated" (along with the cover art) doesn't seem a sufficient clue of suitability.
summary: A mother and daughter in a challenging new world
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed watching this anime DVD about but, truthfully, not enough to be interested in purchasing the next three DVDs and watching them also. The plot of a single mother contending with child welfare services in order to make her own child-rearing choices was different enough to keep me interested for awhile. I've viewed several anime films and series in the last twenty years but I have found my interest waning as I have gotten older. The exagerrated sexuality begins to grate on me after awhile.I found the voice acting and animation on this DVD compared favorably with Vampire Hunter D and Akira, so if you liked those, or if you like anime in general, I am sure you will like this series. If you are not a fan of anime then this is not the DVD that will change your mind.
Title: N/A

reviewText: First, the Easter Egg is outtakes of the tour of the Top Cow studio, and that's amusing.  My favorite part was the interview with Marc Silvestri, one of my all-time favorite comic artists.The first episode of this anime adaptation of the Witchblade story is pretty clunky.  The exposition is delivered by one character telling another character about the big quake that hit Japan six years past, even though everyone in the show obviously is well aware of the disaster.  (That's a minor concern, though, compared to the rest, but I had to mention it because it's a big flaw in a lot of fiction these days.)  The episode sees the Witchblade bearer experience the takeover by the blade for the first time, and kill a murderer at the same time.  She has been forcibly separated from her daughter, though.  The daughter is precocious and mature beyond her years, something that's overdone in a lot of fiction these days.  She's also sickeningly cute to the point of annoyance.  I prefer the scenes with the devious adults a great deal more.We have the Blade bearer taking up with a company that had developed some serious, uh, let's say hardware.  This is the hardware that the witchblade had to take down in the first episode.  Turns out the company lost some of their inventory in the big quake, and only the Witchblade can take them down for the company.  So they task her with another takedown of such a monstrosity, who is killing young women on the street.The third episode has Witchblade reuniting with her daughter and setting her boundaries with her new employer.  The fourth episode has more of the monsters showing up, this time in a group, but before the Witchblade can arrive they are defeated by a pair of women.  Women who resemble the Witchblade greatly.  The episode ends, leaving the viewer wanting a great deal more.  Kind of a dirty trick, but it sure worked on my as I am looking forward to the next installment.There are other characters, like a landlord with a bad attitude, a stereotypical hardboiled detective, and a down-on-his-luck wannabe photojournalist who drives an American left-side-drive car for some reason...  Anyway, there is not enough of the series here to see how the relationships develop, but what is presented here is a solid beginning to a series.
summary: Slow at first, but improving with each episode
Title: N/A

reviewText: "It possesses enormous power, and brings endless pleasure - and destruction - to those who are destined. The Witchblade. At this moment, one woman has awakened."Top Cow Productions' Witchblade comic book, still going strong, made its debut in 1995 and has proven popular enough to spawn a short-lived television series (which starred Yancy Butler). Now its latest evolution has the series crossing international waters and into Japan's world of anime. The  WITCHBLADE anime series, a collaboration between Top Cow and animation group Gonzo Studios, was shown in 24 episodes and garnered great success, coming in 17th out of 90 + animated shows on Japanese television in 2006 (according to Top Cow head honcho Marc Silvestri). And here's WITCHBLADE VOLUME 1 which collects the first four episodes. Now, a gentle warning: Longtime fans of the original Witchblade might be in for a bout of culture shock as Police Detective Sara Pezzini is nowhere to be found here, and the action has migrated from New York to a beleaguered Tokyo set in the near future.For newcomers to the Witchblade mythos, the Witchblade is an ages-old sentient mystical object of awesome destructive force and vast healing powers. Down thru the histories it has chosen a line of women to act as its host, the latest of whom is the unassuming and klutzy Masane Amaha.Six years ago, a devastating earthquake plunged most of Japan underwater. Masane Amaha, caught on ground zero with her newborn child, was rendered amnesiac and cannot now recall anything from before the disaster. Since then, Masane and her clever daughter Rihoko have existed on the outskirts of society, first dwelling in a domestic shelter and then, after eviction, living on the run. Now they're heading back to Tokyo, and trouble, a whole mess of it,  is there to greet them. It begins when the Child Welfare Ministry takes Rihoko away from Masane. Then, as Masane attempts to get back her daughter, the Witchblade at last makes its presence known.This then brings Masane under the unsavory scrutiny of two shadowy factions vying for control of the Witchblade, which is considered the most powerful weapon on earth. One group is the NSWF (National Scientific Welfare Foundation), of which little is known except that the Child Welfare Ministry seems to be a subsidiary. Then there is Doji Group Industries, a giant bioengineering and weapons-manufacturing corporation, of which company head has gone so far as to offer Masane a job. Too, a rash of gruesome city-wide murders somehow ties into things. All these shenanigans do register somewhat on Masane's radar, especially the Witchblade's intrusions, but, understandably, she's much more consumed with reuniting with her daughter.I don't know if I would've called them strong doubts, exactly, but, yeah, I had some reservations going into this one. Sara Pezzini is a great character and, when she had the Witchblade, was a memorable action heroine. In fact, there's some interesting stuff going on currently in her comic book. However, these four episodes, in introducing the new bearer and setting up her universe, intrigued me and whetted my appetite. The animation folks at Gonzo come thru again with very good anime stuff,  doing equal justice to the explosive action sequences and even to the many moments which leaned towards story and character development. There's a generous focus here on Masane's relationship with her daughter, in lieu of constant Witchblade-inflicted mayhem. In fact, it's revealed early on that Masane's overriding motivation centers intensely on Rihoko, that is, when Masane is her normal self.Because, when she's taken over by the Witchblade, she becomes...different. The Witchblade's influence renders Masane extremely bloodthirsty and starved for conflict. Her battle lust seems to border on eroticism, to go by all the licking of lips as her alter ego faces off against various oddly-shaped mechanical monsters. In one instance, when missiles are launched at her, she even exclaims throatily, "Wonderful!" So, if this hasn't been mentioned yet, this dvd (rated TV-MA) is a no-no for kids under a certain age. It's not quite nudity but there are shots galore of Masane's massive "assets." Even her 6 year old daughter, in a scene with an old pervert leering at Internet boobs, is quick to say, "My mom's are way bigger." Yes, Rihoko, they are.Four episodes we get, mere pieces of the whole. It's too early yet for a concreteness to set in, too many permutations in the air, too many machinations being played out. Doubtless there are big reveals and copious bloody violence lurking in the wings. For now, color me very interested. Sign me up for Volumes 2, 3, 4, or however long this series'll take to finish out. I'm there.More, it's indicative of the show's ability to generate interest and hook in fans that episode 4's cliffhanger ending left me howling in protest.A bit on the extra features: there's a laid back, entertaining tour of the cramped (but cool) Top Cow Studios by owner Marc Silvestri; the soft-spoken Mamiko Noto, who voiced Masane Amaha in the original Japanese audio, is interviewed; there's a promotional video; textless songs from the show, including the wistful closing credits song "Ashita no Te" as sung by Mamiko Noto; and a booklet with production artwork and a revealing interview with Director Yoshimitsu Ohashi (for instance, he confirms that the setting is 30 years in the future). Caution: The really tiny printed text in this booklet might induce headaches with its reading.
summary: Um, she licks her lips a lot.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The Witchblade Volume 1 DVD contains, in widescreen format, the first four episodes of the 24-episode anime series inspired by the well-known Top Cow comic book and beautifully animated by GONZO Studios.  The disc's total running time is just over 94 minutes, and includes three vocal tracks: English 5.1 surround, English stereo, and Japanese stereo.  It comes in a clear keepcase encased in a stunning (but very fingerprint-prone) mirror-finished slipcover, decorated with exquisite artwork by Mike Choi.  Extras consist of textless opening and closing songs; a short promotional video; a subtitled interview with Japanese voice actress (and singer of the melodious ending theme), Mamiko Noto; and a tour of Top Cow Studios with Marc Silvestri--owner of Top Cow Productions and the executive producer of this anime project.Six years ago, Masane Amaha was miraculously discovered alive at the epicenter of the Great Earthquake--an area commonly referred to as the Null Point, where the magnetic field reaches zero.  She was clutching an infant.  She had no memory whatsoever of who she was or how she got there, and the only proof that the baby girl in her arms was hers was the maternity diary she had in her possession.  The government created a new identity for her and the child, Rihoko (a.k.a. Riko), and allowed the two to stay for a maximum of six years at a domestic shelter, after which time they were promptly evicted.  Undaunted, Masane decided to move to Tokyo, with young Riko in tow, to start a new life.Along the way, the adventurous twosome meet a friendly boat captain and his equally friendly "Doggy."  After preventing Masane from drowning while observing a flock of yellow rubber duckies, the Captain warns the top-heavy mom that a lot of strange things have been going on in Tokyo recently.He's undoubtedly referring to the horrific "Pulverizer Murders."  The aftermath of one of these dastardly crimes is presently being captured on film by aspiring photo journalist, Yuusuke Tozawa, as he crouches atop an adjacent rooftop.Later, Masame and Rihoko's quiet outdoor lunch is rudely interrupted by odious Child Welfare Ministry agent, Sakurai, who has been relentlessly pursuing the unsuspecting duo ever since their eviction from the shelter.  Sakurai threateningly informs Masane that under the "new laws,"--established because many children were lost in the Great Quake--if she continues to travel around with Rihoko, without a steady job or a permanent home, she will be charged with kidnapping and child endangerment.  "Children need structure," she sternly proclaims, "If the proper environment does not exist, CWM is obligated to take the child into custody."  Eventually, Masane is coerced into consenting to part with her beloved Riko, and the unpleasant busybody drags the little pigtailed tot away yelling, "No! Please, Mom, I wanna live with you!"  When Masane hears Riko's helpless screeches, her maternal instincts kick in and she runs after Sakurai as the self-righteous biddy drives away with tiny Riko locked in the back of the little red automobile, pounding on the windows and pleading for her mommy in a voice reminiscent of a dog's squeaky toy.  Burly police officers try in vain to hold the frantic mother back, and she breaks loose of their grips and dives into an empty police cruiser!  Once she's behind the wheel, Masane hits the accelerator and quickly catches up to Sakurai's car, ramming its side in a desperate effort to reclaim her frightened daughter.  Instead, Masane's black and white cruiser crashes into a guardrail and careens down an embankment.  The cops apprehend the resilient car thief, unscathed, and she winds up in a prison cell at the South Asagaya Detention Center.At the Child Welfare building, Rihoko asks to use the bathroom, where she very cleverly scurries out the window and leaps out into the night air.  She lands directly on the back of Tozawa, the avid photographer, who is more worried about his precious camera then his spine.  In her own inimitable style, little Rihoko implores him to help her escape the clutches of the implacable welfare woman.  Against his better judgment, Tozawa drives the plucky youngster away in his blue muscle car and takes her, at her request, to the Detention Center, where he gets out and looks around.Inside, the odd mark on Masane's wrist begins to glow like Rudolph's nose.  A fellow prisoner in a nearby cell sits up on his cot muttering, "I can smell it in the night...it's wonderful!"  Masane screams in terror as the prisoner rapidly takes on the form of a terrible iron apparatus with multiple pointy protuberances.  The mad machine bursts through the bars and slaughters several guards, reducing them to gooey crimson splats as he makes his way towards Masane's cell.  "It's just you and me now, my darling prey," snarls the mechanical creature.  Horror movie music plays as the spot on Masame's wrist changes from a mere tattoo to a silvery bracelet with a dazzling ruby at its center.  Its wearer's cute, pixie-like face turns bewitchingly demonic.  Her irises take on the appearance of lemon-yellow bug lights...her spikey brown hair turns tomato red...pinkish lines stretch over her plump cheeks...her clothes disappear and are replaced by a skimpy suit of strategically-placed armor!  She is a beautiful, buxom beast, cursed with an uncontrollable urge to eradicate her adversary!  The tiny nostrils of her narrow, turned-up nose flare...an enormous razor-sharp blade extends from her arm...she licks her delicate lips and tears into her monstrous enemy with the ferocious alacrity of a tabby with a fresh bag of catnip!  The pandemonium ends abruptly with an earth-shattering explosion that blows a hole straight through the cement wall of the Detention Center.  As Yuusuke Tozawa watches in stunned disbelief, the steel-clawed babe formerly known as Masane Amaha escapes...and Riko is still on her mind.  Tragically, her brief search for her daughter is cut short by a mysterious bespectacled man with a tranquilizer gun.....Japan's take on Witchblade offers an amazingly compelling and emotional story.  It features simple but elegant animation and interesting characters.  However, some of the villains--like the Microwave Man, who talks just like Mungo from the Heathcliff cartoon show, and literally cooks his victims' innards--may be a bit too weird for some viewers.  I, for one, am anxiously awaiting Volume 2!

reviewText: I'll probably get railed for my review but I am going to be honest: Witchblade is a run-of-the-mill predictable anime. Not that that means it isn't worth watching. For a certain audience, I am sure they would be happy to see a very formulaic anime. I'd say young men from 14-25 ish.Episode 1: The Beginning--First thing I notice is that the main character (who is supposed to be a mother of the young girl shown as well) has huge breasts as do most of the women in the anime.  There is a pretty good car chase but the dialogue is corny and when the main character "transforms" I can't help but noticing how much butt they are showing.Episode 2: The Bewilderment--not much to say. Develops the story more. Filler.Episode 3:  Definace. This episdoe finally got me interested. I liked the cliffhanger type effect at the end of the episode.Episode 4:  Movement--The kid is now finally front and center for us. She is cute, funny and interesting to watch. I think her prescene, if I was watching this on TV or considering buying more of the episodes, would keep me watching more than anything else.So, not a bad anime, but I can't say there was much new here. The animation isn't anything spectacular but isn't awful. Each comment I think of making comes back to--Average. Not bad and not great, but Good.  If you are a fan of anime, especially ones such as Vampire Hunter you will probably find this at least worth a watch!

reviewText: The storyline of "Witchblade" is classic manga, with an interesting twist. Masane, the heroine, is a young mother, who with her 6-year-old daughter, Rihoko, struggles to cope after a disaster wipes out their home. Regaining her memory, she finds herself on the run and burdened with a mysterious glowing bracelet. Whenever Rihoko is threatened -- by a child welfare agency trying to putting her into foster care, or by mostrous felons -- Masane morphs painfully into a superhuman warrior. Aside from the government agency trying to help her, there are industrialists trying to capture her and regain possession of the bracelet, which courses with the power of the Witchblade, an ancient power-giving object. Masane must navigate between these powerful interests, with the reluctant help of a young freelance cameraman, to rid herself of the cursed Witchblade and gain her daughter's freedom.The story line of WitchBlade is engaging, and its characters symptathetic and nuanced. The child welfare group is truly doing what seems in the girl's best interests. Masane truly (and convincingly) loves her daughter, but is really not in control of her life. Her possession of the Witchblade is her greatest strength, but also her greatest distress and the cause of her separation from Rihoko. I particularly loved the writing, as voiced by the actors, which was energetic and fun.There are elements of the film I could do without. The script, as spelled out in the subtitles, was horrible and dull. I've never seen subtitles vary so much from the words spoken on screen. And the enormous voyeuristic element that was Masane's bustline distracted from an already-great storyline. This distraction only doubled (no pun intended?) when Masane morphed into her alter ego, a three-quarter naked warrior with naught but wisps of costume to conceal her "armaments." Gratuitous through-the crotch shots didn't help. Ho-ly Hannah, help us! The story is episodic, like a Saturday morning cartoon, complete with intro and outro music and credits. Watch these once and then skip the rest.Yet, I got a kick out of this story of mother-as-manga-monster. It isn't suitable forn the preteens in your life, but might be fun for the 17-25-year-old male who can tolerate likes a decent story with a lot of female anatomy without having his head explode. Not so sure about the young ladies, who might be put off by the near-nudity or appreciate a strong female character. Your call.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This new interpretation of Witchblade has a lot of potential.  This is not a traditional film, but is told in series episodes (like Hellsing or Trinity Blood).  Volume 1 collects the first four episodes and introduces a new bearer for the weapon.  Amaha lives in Tokyo years after a massive earthquake devastated the city. She has a six year old daughter that the Child Welfare Agency is trying to take away.  The head of a powerful corporation takes them in to get her to use the witchblade to hunt down some rogue android-like machines that have been killing women all over the city.This version has a new twist to the tale - a secret organization whose members also seem to have witchblades!  Who will control Amaha?  Who is her real enemy?  These four episodes were fast paced despite having to provide introductory material.  Episode four ends with the startling revelation of the other "witchblade" bearers, leaving a bit of a cliffhanger.  Those who have seen the live action show, or read the comics, will connect more with the story but anyone can enjoy this.  The animation is very nice though occasionally characters are out of proportion.  Amaha's witchblade costume is very sexy, but slightly laughable in that her backside appears completely bare.  The DVD is in English with an excellent cast of voice actors.Overall, I highly recommend this series. I intend to buy volume 2 as soon as it is available.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Witchblade Vol. 1 is a great DVD presentation for the japanese animation series. This slick and stylish DVD comes with the first four episodes with english and japanese soundtracks along with english sub-titles.  The epsiodes are uncut and in 16.9 widescreen format.  Also included along with a few supplement extras (interview with Marc Silvestri along with a guided tour of his studios) is a very informative 8 page booklet that introduces the main characters of the series.I have never seen the anime before and I has hooked after the first episode.  I would watch the original dialog soundtrack because the acting is not only better, but the writing is more solid and it's not corny or annoying.  The direction is very slick and the show moves like a video game with a lot of quick cuts and flashy editing.  If youy love anime or enjoy the Witchblade manga (which this is based upon) go out and snag a copy!Highly recommended.

reviewerName: K. Eckert "Devourer of all books fantasy"
reviewText: You can tell this is made by the same people that did Elven Leid.  I personally loved Elfen Leid.  As with that series there is a ton of graphic violence and the lead female has crazy tentacle like things she can do a lot of damage with.The main character, Masane, has amnesia and a[..]daughter.  Child welfare is on her case to hand her daughter over, since Masane keeps finding herself in bad situations and unable to support them both.  When her daughter is taken by child welfare she finds herself in a desperate chase to get her daughter back.  When she is in danger a strange bracelet on her wrists pulses and she transforms into the Witchblade bearer; a truly kick-butt fighter.The animation and dubbing are both top-notch.  The story is intriguing and the action scenes are wonderful.  The characters are enjoyable.  Although this anime seems a little more geared at catching the guys eyes than the ladies.  Special attention is given to the female characters chests (which defy gravity) and Masane's costume as Witchblade barely covers at all.  The biggest disappointment at this point is that there are no particularly sexy male leads.People who find violence disturbing should find something else to watch.  Those who love the violence and fighting of Elfen Leid or Hellsing should get a kick out of this anime.  Witchblade Masane finds blood and violence erotically exciting and that may be disturbing to some people as well.  Definitely an anime for a mature audience.I loved it and proceeded to buy the complete series online after watching it.
summary: Promising start to the series...uber violence and disturbing characters

reviewText: I must admit that I'm a bit of a novice when it comes to this form of animation. I have watched a few others and particularly liked Grave of the fireflies. Totally different.Witchblade is a strange one. It moves effortlessly from being a superhero tale, to a sci-fi, to a comedy, to a gorefest, to a chick flick, then spiced up to an R+ rating, maybe even softporn-lite.This volume contains the first four episodes of the Japanese TV series: The Beginning, Bewilderment, Defiance and Movement. (Hopefully they show it after 10PM) Other reviewers have done a nice job explaining the storyline so I won't reiterate other than to say it's an easy-to-follow one, unlike some anime/manga offerings, and its rapidly changing genres keep you on your toes.It's definitely worth watching for the art, the music, the over-the-top fights and the pure sexiness of it.Witchblade might be a little intense if you're new to this art form or it might make you a real fan. If you're a veteran watcher, you must add this to your must-watch list.I just added Volume II to my list.
summary: Watch this one, but not with little children

reviewText: On the run from the Child Welfare Department that wants to take her 6-year-old daughter away from her, jobless and homeless Masane Amaha has come to Tokyo for a new start. Masane is a beautiful young woman with a tragic past. She remembers nothing of her life before a destructive earthquake hit six years earlier. When the Child Welfare Dept. catches up to her once again, she makes one final, desperate act to keep little Rihoko and lands herself in prison. While there, a confrontation with a local murderer that is more than what he appears brings out a hidden power in Masane. She has been endowed with the Witchblade, an ancient, living weapon that attaches itself to select women throughout the ages, turning them into savage warriors to satisfy its lust for violence and blood. As Masane's battle in prison allows for her escape, her clever daughter Rihoko pulls off an escape of her own with the help of a photographer with journalistic ambitions. Rihoko eventually makes her way to her mother's secret meeting place, but will Masane make it there too? She'll first have to work out an arrangement with a mysterious company that wants control of the Witchblade and whoever possesses its power."Witchblade" Volume 1 gives us the first 4 episodes of what seems to be an excellent 2006 Japanese animated series (Anime) based on the successful American "Top Cow" comic book series. No doubt, this animated series will get mixed responses from fans of the comics and the short-lived live-action TV series starring Yancy Butler from 2001. The reason for this, besides the fact that not everyone appreciates Anime, is that it has nothing to do with Sara Pezzini or any other Witchblade characters established in the United States. While it is my understanding that this Anime series IS considered canon, the characters and story are completely new and completely Japanese. But so what? The art is top notch for Anime, and this is coming from someone who is far more into American animation. The characters and story are engaging, and there's plenty of the traditional Anime violence and sex appeal too. While the show, thus far, doesn't have the overall darkness and grit one sees in the Top Cow comics, it's certainly not bubbly, cutesy Anime. This is definitely for the grown ups, and, after all, these are only the first four episodes. They have their sweet and colorful Ghibli-type moments, but they have their darkness too. Anime fans in general would probably love this, and for those who are less familiar with the genre, perhaps you have seen an American show called "Gargoyles?" If you enjoyed that show (probably the finest American animated series ever), you'll probably get some enjoyment out of this too.With only the first four episodes, the Volume One DVD certainly leaves one wanting more. The episodes included are: The Beginning, Bewilderment, Defiance, and Movement. There are some nice extras included as well. The best is probably the fun tour of Top Cow Studios in Hollywood, led by owner Marc Silvestri. There's also a nice interview with lovely voice actress Mamiko Noto, who voices Masane in the original Japanese language. Yes, the DVD includes the original Japanese language, English subtitles, and English language versions. And, yes, there are differences between the Japanese and English language versions of Anime, so it's best to watch them both. One wants to see the more accurate text translations, but it's easier to enjoy the visuals fully when you don't have to try to keep up with reading the dialogue. The bonus features also include several Anime DVD trailers, video versions of the opening and closing songs, and a promotional video. The DVD is packaged with one of those cool, silvery slip covers that look great until you touch them and get your nasty fingerprints all over them. It's also the "opens like a book" kind. Plus, inside are two booklets. Okay, one is a little catalog. The other is an actual bonus. It's a booklet featuring production art and a great interview with the director, Yoshimitsu Ohashi. I highly recommend this DVD for fans of Anime, of Witchblade, of animation and comics in general, or just someone looking for a more adult kind of animated program. I'll be looking forward to future volumes!
Title: N/A

reviewText: It is said, by Westerners who have lived and worked there, that Japanese culture and society are so foreign to ours that most of us can't even comprehend the differences, nevermind their causes and effects.  Perhaps the one popular medium where we get some feel for the divergence is the increasingly popular Japanese anime market.  Even the most accessible films--the Ghibli Studio stuff or an adaptation of classic American animation, like Little Nemo--have aspects, subplots or even large swathes of narrative that are basically incomprehensible.  Take a great family film like Kiki's Delivery Service: it's not only impossible to tell where or when the story is taking place but so much of the underlying mythos is left unexplained that each step of the plot is surprising, if only because it seems so odd.This adaptation of the American comic book Witchblade is kind of like a Miyazaki film in ways both bad and good.  On the plus side, the animation is terrific, pretty nearly Disney worthy, making it easy to watch.  The voice work and translation is good too, so the extent anything makes sense we can follow it, which isn't always the case with Asian imports.  This is a high quality art work.The setting is the typical -- for anime -- post-apocalyptic world of big corporations and dubious government agencies combined with supernatural/metaphysical weirdness that beggars comprehension.  A young woman who has survived whatever destruction is supposed to have occurred came out of the blast with a child and, at opportune moments, the titular witchblade, a metallic prosthetic hand which appears as she changes into some kind of magical being.  Well-endowed to begin with, she loses a significant amount of clothing in the transition and becomes an erotic killing machine.It all makes for great-looking eye candy, but the literary merits are debatable and it's hard to be either profound or emotionally-moving when you're challenging the viewer just to try and figure out what's going on.

reviewText: The seperate Witchblade storyline that starts in this series is surprisingly well written and engaging despite being a bit removed from its source material.  The mother and daughter team that are thrown into a War with the powers that be is the stuff that any good anime is made of, the artwork is above average and the animation could be a little more fluid but it is standard for this genre. I would have loved an animated adaptation of the original Witchblade comic series done in a more lush fashion but this is an excellent substitute and could prove popular with non anime fans if they ever gave it a shot.  The DVD is nicely packaged in a platinum slip case and their are a couple of worthy extras M. Choi's cover art looks killer and the interview with Silverstri is intersting for fans. Original language options are nice for those who prefer subtitles although the english voice work is above average.  This disc is the first four episodes and clocks in at roughly 99 mins.
summary: A quality expansion on the Witchblade storyline in Anime form
Title: N/A

reviewText: This Japanese anime is based on the US comic of the same name, but it uses different characters. The story starts six years after an earthquake devastated Tokyo, when Masane Amaha and her daughter Rihoko are returning to the capital in search of their destiny. Sadly, Child Welfare is looking for them because Masane cannot provide a stable environment for her child, and the government organization soon takes Rihoko away. These are heart-wrenching moments and give us already a sense about the nature of this series.Masane is not your normal single mom though, since she has the Witchblade, which can be defined as Earth's greatest weapon that has existed since the dawn of mankind and that chooses women, based on some unknown criteria, to be wielded by them. As expected, there are many people secretly trying to control this power, which allows for an extremely interesting plot, involving various murders, automats designed to kill, and much more.When I started watching this DVD I was expecting a powerful action story, with a great amount of fights, but as the actress that provides the voice for Masane comments in the extras, this story can be defined much better as a human drama. The plot is really enthralling and contains a level of emotion seldom seen in anime, but the fights in this first volume are a little lacking in complexity and challenge. It is clear though that in the next volumes we are going to get much better action as more characters with singular fighting abilities emerge.The graphics are crisp and clear and follow the typical pattern used in this genre. The creators can show off their talent a little more due to the characteristics of the heroine when transformed by the Witchblade, since she wears a revealing outfit that accentuates her voluptuous body. The music is pleasant and the lyrics fit well with the story, and the beginning and ending themes create a nice contrast. Also, there are some secondary characters that provide some passing humor that helps liven up the mood when the story needs it.In the Extras, there are two features of interest. There is a tour of the Top Cow offices, the publisher and creator of the comic in the US, guided by a witty Marc Silvestri, who is one of the authors and editors. When I saw what this was about I expected a boring segment, but instead I found an entertaining piece that left me wanting to know more about this company and their products. The other extra feature I think was informative was the interview with the actress that plays Masane's voice in the Japanese audio. She had some interesting insights to share about the characters and the series overall, but I was extremely surprised by the fact that she had not read the comic. Finally, there is an Easter egg which contains deleted scenes from the tour of Top Cow. In order to play this you need to go to the Extras and hit left on your remote when standing on the first extra feature, a W will illuminate on the bottom left on the screen and you will be able to access this segment.Overall this is a very good start to the series and it certainly left me wanting more, especially due to the intriguing ending to the last episode of the disc. I am definitely going to keep watching this new series, and I will probably even go back and read the comics for the US version. I may just have found a new favorite!
summary: "I'm not certain whether she was lucky to have survived or cursed"

Title: N/A

reviewText: Witchblade started off as a break through concept from Image comics. It garnered critical success and has a healthy following at comic book stores everywhere. This has led to a short lived television series and now it has somehow gained the interest of the Japanese with its very own anime.It should be mentioned that this is a purely for adults only. Its violent, sexually suggestive, and contains mature subject matter. We meet Masane Amou as she struggles to keep her daughter away from child welfare and be a decent single mom. She seems unprepared for the trials of motherhood as it seems from the get-go that her daughter is the one doing all of the lecturing and rearing but the thought of losing her daughter leads our heroine to do a little growing up of her own. It seems that during an earthquake the witchblade bonded itself to her person and has now manifested its power turning her into a deadly warrior.The series takes off to a bumpy start as its difficult to feel anything for such an incompetant mother. I don't care too much seeing the beautifully detailed and dark comic turned into a bubbly big eyed anime adventure. Granted the subejct matter has maintained alot of what made it so great originally it seems watered down by the simplistic and predictable art design. I remember seeing a statue a few months back of the Witchblade and thought it was a neat take on the well known comic design but after seeing it in motion I have lost my admiration for the design. Its not the enhanced bust or booty of the main character, instead its that the over all tone is light hearted and contains all of the aspects that I have come to strongly dislike about anime in general. I prefer the animation of Satoshi Kon where facial features are distinct and highly detailed. Instead with witchblade we return to the "everyone is a charicature" drawn world that we see time and time again in japanese animation these days.The DVD contains only the first four episodes so story wise this is just a stepping stone and it does a decent job at aquainting you with the universe. Hopefully it will get better although much of the damage is already done with the art style and that is not likely to change. Fans of the comic may not settle for the new look of their favorite female killer. I sure didn't.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I didn't quite know what I was getting myself into when I started watching The Witchblade.  My only introduction to The Witchblade comes in the form of her character's (from the comic book) cross-over into The Darkness, another comic produced by Top Cow Productions.  This Witchblade stars Ara Pezzini, a "tough as nails" NYPD detective who comes into contact with the sentient artifact called The Witchblade when she is mortally wounded and the blade chooses her as its next in line of users.  This particular DVD series, an anime licenses from Top Cow, is completely different.  While I had done some initial research to see what, exactly, the comic book series was about (thinking the anime would simply be a Japanese take on the series), none of what I found really fits in with the DVD.This particular edition of The Witchblade details the story of Masane Amaha who, during a catastrophe in Tokyo, ends losing her memory and discovers a mysterious jewel attached to her wrist and a baby who she names Rihoko in her arms.  Six years later, and Masane realizes the jewel attached to her wrist is actually The Witchblade that has chosen her as its new wielder.  The series details her travails as she's caught between a huge corporation and the government when all she wants to do is take care of her child and live in peace.  This is the bigger, over-arching story of The Witchblade anime.Volume One contains the first three episodes which basically sets up the action that will follow.  They introduce the National Scientific Welfare Foundation (NSWF) and Reina Soho who want to take Rihoko from Masane because Masane does not have a job and, according to the NSWF, can't take care of Rihoko.  Additional characters are introduced, like Reiji Takayama, the Bureau Chief of Douji Group Industries, who wants to hire Masane.  The main conflict is between the NSWF and Masane for these beginning episodes.Obviously this isn't the entire season, unfortunately, so it's merely a taste of what's to come.  I'm impressed, though, already and am curious to see where the story will go from here.  The art style is very interesting, taking a cue from the original Top Cow comics and adding a Japanese flair to the proceedings.  It's a pretty vicious and dark anime and this unrated cut apparently recolors the costume and skin color of Masane.  One of the side effects of using the Witchblade, apparently, is losing one's clothes and in the TV version of this show, some of the skin was darkened in black to avoid excessive nudity.  The coloring has been restored for this edition.  Additionally, the presentation is great and cleaned up from the television series.Audio is always tricky on US imports of anime.  The voice actors chosen for the English voices usually tend to ruin the experience.  While I've heard much, much worse translations, the English dubbing isn't the way to go.  Overall, this is a great start to a new take on The Witchblade.  While it's merely a taste, there's a hook in it that I'm willing to let drag me onward.  Here's hoping more volumes are forthcoming soon.
summary: Great introduction to a very adult series

reviewText: I was never a huge fan of the Witchblade series when I collected comic books, but I occasinally enjoyed reading them.  I was interested in this DVD based on my previous exposure from the comic books.When I started watching the four episodes I realized this was not the Witchblade I was use to. Gone was Sara Pezzini as the Witchblade bearer and gone was the look and feel of the Top Cow comic book.  All to be replaced by Japanese anime and a new storyline.The stories are different and not being a fan of anime, the way the story flows is different.  It was difficult to was the stories because they are segmented and very choppy.  It seems much of the in between story is left out and left to the viewer to figure out.The soundtrack is mediocre at best.  It sounds like it was produced on some guys synth and there is little background ambiance noise.  I swear most of the background voices were dubbed by the same man and woman.The animation is fine, for anime.  But that style just does not appeal to me.  For true fans of anime and Witchblade, this might be a good buy.  But for others, go into it knowing this is a different Witchblade.
summary: Not the witchblade I used to read
